Introduction

Limb development is a highly coordinated process involving the precise expression (both in time and location) of various signaling factors that are regulated by certain genes, including homeobox (HOX) genes.  Disruptions in this process can result in limb development disorders that range in severity and presentation.

Normal limb growth and development



At the end of week 4 of gestation, the upper and lower limb buds form from the ventrolateral wall of the embryo.  Each limb bud contains a core of mesenchymal cells that is covered by ectoderm.  The mesenchymal cells give rise to bones, tendons, and other connective tissues, and the ectoderm gives rise to skin.  In addition, cells from segments of adjacent mesoderm (ie, somites) migrate to the limb buds and form muscles.  These basic structures (eg, bones, muscles, skin) are established by the end of week 8 of gestation.



Segmental organization (proper positioning of structures) of the embryo from the cranial to the caudal direction is controlled by HOX genes (

figure 1
).  HOX genes code for transcription factors that regulate the expression of genes involved in cell differentiation and positioning in early embryogenesis.  There is a spatial relationship between the location of the homeobox gene and its expression along the craniocaudal axis:  Genes located near the 3′ end are expressed cranially, and genes located near the 5′ end are expressed caudally.  HOX gene mutations (eg, gain-of-function, loss-of-function) can lead to improper sequencing of body segments, causing structures to develop in the wrong location, number, or shape.



Following craniocaudal segmental organization, limb growth and development are further regulated to ensure proper limb orientation, as follows:



  • Proximal-distal orientation:  The apical ectodermal ridge (AER) is located at the distal limb bud and directs limb elongation by secreting growth factors (eg, fibroblast growth factor [FGF]) that induce rapid proliferation of adjacent mesenchymal cells.  As the limb elongates, the mesenchymal cells that are farthest from the AER differentiate into muscle and cartilage.  Limb elongation therefore occurs in a proximal-to-distal direction.  The fingers and toes develop last, around week 6.  At this time, the distal end of the limbs flattens, and regions of the AER undergo apoptosis to form 5 separate digits.
  • Cranial-caudal orientation (ie, thumb to fifth finger):  This orientation is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA), which is a cluster of cells located at the posterior side of the limb bud.  The ZPA produces retinoic acid, which induces expression of the sonic hedgehog (SHH) gene.  The SHH gene directs digit patterning, including apoptosis of the AER.
  • Ventral-dorsal orientation (eg, palm/flexor side to dorsal/extensor side):  This orientation is regulated by several factors, including bone morphogenetic proteins expressed in the ventral ectoderm and the WNT7 gene.


These additional regulatory factors also interact with HOX genes to determine the types of bones in the limb (eg, radius vs ulna formation).  Additional formation of the main limb structures includes:



  • Bone formation:  Bones form from preexisting cartilaginous tissue, a process known as endochondral ossification.  Bone formation begins around week 6, when mesenchymal cells condense into chondrocytes.  Osteoblasts migrate to this cartilaginous structure and deposit bone matrices.  Bone growth is maintained by FGF signaling and continues through birth.
  • Limb muscle:  During limb elongation, cells from somites migrate to the limb buds and compartmentalize into flexor and extensor muscle components.  Meanwhile, peripheral nerve fibers, derived from the neural crest, begin innervating the muscles.
  • Limb rotation:  The upper and lower limb buds undergo rotations required for proper positioning.  Around week 8, the upper limbs rotate laterally 90 degrees, resulting in the elbows pointing posteriorly; the lower limbs rotate medially 90 degrees, resulting in the knees pointing anteriorly.

Congenital limb defect types



Because limb development depends on the precise coordination of various signaling factors, many opportunities exist for abnormal development, leading to limb defects.  Congenital limb defects can occur in isolation or be associated with other genetic syndromes.  These defects can be categorized into the following:



  • Reduction defects include complete absence of a limb (amelia) and partial absence of a limb (meromelia).  Reduction defects can occur due to loss of FGF signaling or exposure to certain drugs (eg, thalidomide) in utero.
  • Duplication defects include polydactyly (presence of extra digits) and triphalangeal thumb (3 phalanges instead of 2).  Duplication defects can occur due to the upregulation of SHH by the ZPA.
  • Dysplasias (ie, abnormalities in limb shape, size, or structure) include syndactyly (fused digits) due to failed apoptosis.
  • Disproportionate growth leads to brachydactyly (shortened digits) and arachnodactyly (elongated digits).
  • Deformations occur due to external physical insults that interrupt and arrest development, including amniotic band entanglement and constriction of limbs, leading to amputations in utero.

Evaluation



The diagnosis of a limb development disorder is based on clinical examination findings.  Imaging (eg, radiographs) can help determine the extent of bony involvement in some defects.  Depending on the specific defect, patients may benefit from genetic testing (eg, HOX gene panel sequencing, karyotyping, chromosomal microarray), particularly if multiple congenital anomalies suggest an underlying syndrome.

Management



Management involves a multidisciplinary approach, with pediatric genetics, orthopedic surgery, and plastic surgery working in consultation to restore function and cosmesis.  Patients often benefit from physical and occupational therapies.  Genetic counseling may also be considered.

Summary



Limb development is a highly coordinated process that involves the precise expression (both in time and location) of various signaling factors that are regulated by certain genes, including homeobox (HOX) genes.  Disruptions in this process can result in limb development disorders that range in severity and presentation.  Management of congenital limb development disorders may include imaging, genetic testing, and surgical intervention to restore function and cosmesis.
